set out.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to start a journey, especially a long journey
set out.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The band are setting out on a European tour in March.
set out on a journey/drive/voyage etc
Kate set out for the house on the other side of the bay.
set out.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to start doing something or making plans to do something in order to achieve a particular result
set out.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: They set out with the aim of becoming the number one team in the league.
set out with the idea/purpose/intention etc of doing something
salesmen who deliberately set out to defraud customers
set out.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to explain ideas, facts, or opinions in a clearly organized way, in writing or in a speech
set out.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: He set out the reasons for his decision in his report.
set out.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to put a group of things down and arrange them
set out.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The market traders began setting out their displays.
set out.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to start doing something, especially something new, difficult, or important
set out.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: My nephew is just setting out on a career in journalism.
set out.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to write or talk about something, such as a group of facts, ideas, or reasons in an organized way
set out.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Details of the case are set out in a briefing paper.
The performance measurement system sets out what tasks each person is responsible for.
set out.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to start a particular kind of job or start doing something in a particular way
set out.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The new government set out to manage inflation by using interest rates to control the money supply.
